text.title: Jan Suchorzewski
text.head: Jan Suchorzewski
text.p:
Jan Suchorzewski
( 1740 or 1754 – 1804 or 1809 )
[ a ]
was a
Polish noble
of the
Zaremba coat of arms
, soldier and politician . He held the title of the
wojski
of
Wschowa
.
[ 1 ]
He was a deputy from
Gniezno
to the
Sejm
( parliament ) of 1786 and deputy from
Kalisz
to the
Great Sejm
of 1788-1792 .
[ 1 ]
He would be best remembered for his dramatic , theatrical gestures from that period .
Kazimierz Bartoszewicz
compared Suchorzewski 's look and attitude to that of
Zagłoba
from
Henryk Sienkiewicz
' s
famous trilogy
, if more misguided .
[ 2 ]
He became an opponent of the reforms , and joined the
Confederation of Targowica
.
[ 1 ]
text.head: Biography
text.p:
Jan was born in 1740 or 1754 as the son of Jakub Suchorzewski and Jadwiga Zajączek .
[ 3 ]
Around 1770 he married Joanna Przyjemska ; they had three children .
[ 3 ]

During the Great Sejm Suchorzewski was at first a supporter of the
Patriotic Party
; in particular he supported the enlargement of the
Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth
' s army .
[ 4 ]
[ 5 ]
[ 6 ]
In 1789 he published a brochure on the cities and law (
Basics of urban laws
-
Zasady praw miejskich
) .
[ 7 ]
However , he eventually switched sides and joined the
Hetman Party
opposed to the reforms .
[ 1 ]
[ 4 ]
Around 18 January 1791 he criticized the recently premiered
The Return of the Deputy
(
Powrót posła
) comedy of
Julian Ursyn Niemcewicz
for its political content ; his critique was not well received and he was ridiculed for it , losing prestige .
[ 8 ]
[ 9 ]
[ 10 ]
Despite his opposition of many reforms , he nonetheless played a major , if perhaps not necessarily intentional ,
[ 11 ]
role in the passage of the
Free Royal Cities Act
in April 1791 , as his rather unexpected involvement in the discussion boosted the supporters of the act and eased its passing .
[ 12 ]
[ 13 ]
For that , the king rewarded him with the
Order of Saint Stanislaus
.
[ 10 ]

Suchorzewski unsuccessfully attempted to prevent the king from signing the
Constitution of 3 May
, blocking his way and threatening to kill his own son to save him from the " slavery of the Constitution " .
[ 14 ]
[ 15 ]
[ 16 ]
[ b ]
In this way he repeated , in an infamous , or tragicomic way , the gesture of
Tadeusz Rejtan
.
[ 17 ]
[ 18 ]
This incident was immortalized on
Jan Matejko
' s painting
Constitution of May 3 , 1791
.
[ 14 ]
[ 15 ]
From Suchorzewski 's pocket , a deck of cards has fallen out , an allusion to the way he was bribed by the Hetman Party leaders , Russian ambassador
Otto Magnus von Stackelberg
and
hetman
Branicki
.
[ 14 ]
[ 14 ]
[ 15 ]
Later , he would publish a critique of the constitution in the brochure
Uwagi nad konstytucją polską 3 maja 1791
(
Notes on the Polish Constitution of 3 May 1791
)
[ 7 ]
and
Odezwa do narodu wraz z protestacyją dla Śladu Gwałtu i Przemocy , do której prawie w całym Sejmie zbliżano , a w dniu 3 maja 1791 dokonano
(
A Declaration to the Nation with a Protestation for the Evidence of Rape and Violence which was Planned throughout most of the Sejm and on day 3 May 1791 Carried out
) .
[ 19 ]

text.p:
Suchorzewski , with several other opponents of the constitution , departed to
Saint Petersburg
in the
Russian Empire
, where he became one of the founding members and high-ranking officials (
konsyliarz
) of the
Confederation of Targowica
.
[ 1 ]
[ 20 ]
[ 21 ]
Derdej speculated that out of all those who signed the act of the Confederation , Suchorzewski was the only one who might have thought they were really acting in the country 's best interest .
[ 17 ]
He commanded a cavalry brigade in the Confederation forces during the
War in Defense of the Constitution
that the Confederates eventually won , overthrowing the Constitution . During the
Kościuszko Insurrection
he was sentenced ,
in absentia
, to a death by hanging , eternal
infamy
, loss of all titles and confiscation of possessions . His
effigy
was hanged on the 29 September 1794 .
[ 22 ]
